title: What causes opioid addiction, and why is it so tough to combat? - Mike Davis

multiple-choice.question: What plant is the source of opium?
Which compound was identified and isolated for medical use in the 19th century?
What term describes synthetic substances similar to opiates?
What is the primary reason why opioids are highly addictive?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they bind strongly to opioid receptors in the brain, triggering the release of dopamine and altering the body's natural response to pain

options.label: D
options.text: Because they can alter the body's natural response to pain

multiple-choice.question: What neurotransmitter is linked to feelings of pleasure and may be responsible for the sense of euphoria that characterizes an opioid high?
What term describes the process by which the body becomes dependent on opioids to maintain a balance of noradrenaline?
What are the primary symptoms of opioid withdrawal?
What medication is currently used as a defense against opioid overdose?
What is the primary goal of opioid maintenance programs?

options.label: A
options.text: To eliminate opioid abuse using a combination of medication and behavior therapy

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the helpline operated by the Department of Health and Human Services for people struggling with opioid use in the United States?

title: What is society? | US society for children

multiple-choice.question: What is a society?

options.label: A
options.text: A group of people who live in the same neighborhood

options.label: B
options.text: A large group of people who share the same laws, rights, and resources

options.label: C
options.text: A group of people who speak the same language

options.label: D
options.text: A group of people who do the same type of work

multiple-choice.question: What do people in a society typically share?

options.label: D
options.text: Cultural communities, but not necessarily laws, rights, and resources

multiple-choice.question: Can people in a society live far away from each other?

options.label: A
options.text: No, they must live close to each other

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, they can live far away from each other

options.label: C
options.text: It depends on the type of society

options.label: D
options.text: People in all societies must live close to each other

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a society where people can live far away from each other?

options.label: B
options.text: A group of people who do the same type of work

options.label: D
options.text: A city or a country with many communities

multiple-choice.question: What do people in American society share?

options.label: C
options.text: The same flag, voting rights, and leadership

multiple-choice.question: Can a society be a group of people who do the same type of work?

options.label: A
options.text: No, a society must be a group of people who live close to each other

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, a society can be a group of people who do the same type of work

options.label: C
options.text: It depends on the type of society

options.label: D
options.text: A society can be a group of people with shared interests, but not necessarily a specific type of work

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a society where people do the same type of work?

options.label: B
options.text: A group of people who believe in something together

options.label: D
options.text: A group of doctors or animal protection volunteers

multiple-choice.question: Can a society be a group of people who believe in something together?

options.label: A
options.text: No, a society must be a group of people who live close to each other

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, a society can be a group of people who believe in something together

options.label: C
options.text: It depends on the type of society

options.label: D
options.text: A society can be a group of people with shared values, but not necessarily a specific belief

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a society where people believe in something together?

options.label: B
options.text: A group of people who do the same type of work

options.label: D
options.text: A group of people who believe in animal protection

multiple-choice.question: What type of societies do you belong to?

options.label: B
options.text: Only societies where people live close to each other

options.label: C
options.text: Societies where people share common interests or values

multiple-choice.question: What is the difference between a hypothesis and a theory in scientific research?

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: A hypothesis is a scientific law, while a theory is a mathematical equation

title: Which is better: Soap or hand sanitizer? - Alex Rosenthal and Pall Thordarson

multiple-choice.question: What are two simple ways to prevent a virus from infecting you through your hands?

options.label: A
options.text: Soap and water, and hand sanitizer

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of the lipid bilayer on the surface of the coronavirus that causes COVID-19?

options.label: A
options.text: To provide structural support to the virus

options.label: B
options.text: To break through cellular membranes and hijack cells

options.label: C
options.text: To protect the virus from environmental factors

options.label: D
options.text: To facilitate the transmission of the virus

multiple-choice.question: How do soap molecules help to break down the lipid bilayer of the coronavirus?

options.label: A
options.text: By forming a physical barrier around the virus

options.label: B
options.text: By competing with the lipids for space and disrupting the regularity of the virus's membrane

options.label: C
options.text: By releasing enzymes that degrade the lipids

options.label: D
options.text: By increasing the temperature of the surrounding environment

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary mechanism by which hand sanitizer kills the coronavirus?

options.label: A
options.text: By drying out the virus and disrupting its lipid bilayer

options.label: B
options.text: By forming a physical barrier around the virus

options.label: C
options.text: By releasing enzymes that degrade the virus's proteins

options.label: D
options.text: By destabilizing the virus's membrane and causing it to collapse

multiple-choice.question: Why is it recommended to wash hands with soap and water for at least 20 seconds?

options.label: A
options.text: To ensure that the soap has time to fully break down the lipid bilayer of the virus

options.label: B
options.text: To allow the soap to reach all areas of the hand, including between the fingers and under the nails

options.label: C
options.text: To increase the effectiveness of the soap in killing the virus

options.label: D
options.text: To reduce the risk of skin irritation

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary benefit of using soap and water to wash hands compared to hand sanitizer?

options.label: A
options.text: Soap and water is more convenient to use

options.label: B
options.text: Soap and water is more effective at killing the virus

options.label: C
options.text: Soap and water can wash away dirt and debris that may be hiding virus particles

options.label: D
options.text: Soap and water is more expensive than hand sanitizer

multiple-choice.question: Why is it recommended to use hand sanitizer in the absence of a sink?

options.label: A
options.text: Because hand sanitizer is more effective at killing the virus than soap and water

options.label: B
options.text: Because hand sanitizer is more convenient to use on the go

options.label: C
options.text: Because hand sanitizer is more environmentally friendly than soap and water

options.label: D
options.text: Because hand sanitizer is more cost-effective than soap and water

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary mechanism by which the device that uses salt, water, and a car battery makes chlorinated water?

options.label: A
options.text: By releasing chlorine gas into the water

options.label: B
options.text: By adding chlorine tablets to the water

options.label: C
options.text: By using an electrolysis process to generate chlorine

options.label: D
options.text: By using a UV light to disinfect the water

multiple-choice.question: Why is it recommended to follow the advice of accredited medical professionals when determining the best way to prevent the spread of a viral outbreak?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they have access to the latest research and data on the virus

options.label: B
options.text: Because they have experience in treating similar outbreaks

options.label: C
options.text: Because they can provide personalized advice based on individual circumstances

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary difference between the coronavirus that causes COVID-19 and the rhinoviruses that cause common colds?

options.label: A
options.text: The coronavirus has a lipid bilayer, while the rhinoviruses have a geometric protein structure called a capsid

options.label: B
options.text: The coronavirus has a geometric protein structure called a capsid, while the rhinoviruses have a lipid bilayer

options.label: C
options.text: The coronavirus is more contagious than the rhinoviruses

options.label: D
options.text: The coronavirus is more severe than rhinoviruses

title: The science of lucid dreaming

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of sensory memory?

options.label: B
options.text: To store information for an extended period

options.label: C
options.text: To briefly store a snapshot of sensory information, such as a visual image or a sound

options.label: D
options.text: To retrieve information from long-term memory

multiple-choice.question: Which type of memory is responsible for the temporary storage of information?
What happens to information in sensory memory?

options.label: C
options.text: It's transferred to short-term memory if it receives selective attention

multiple-choice.question: Which type of memory is responsible for the permanent storage of information?
What is an example of sensory memory?

options.label: B
options.text: Taking a picture with a camera

options.label: C
options.text: Seeing a brief visual image, such as a flash of a face or a sunset

multiple-choice.question: What happens to information in short-term memory?

options.label: C
options.text: It's forgotten or lost unless rehearsed or consolidated

multiple-choice.question: What is the difference between short-term and long-term memory?

options.label: A
options.text: Short-term memory stores information for a long period, while long-term memory stores information temporarily

options.label: B
options.text: Short-term memory stores information temporarily, while long-term memory stores information permanently

options.label: C
options.text: Both short-term and long-term memory store information temporarily

options.label: D
options.text: Both short-term and long-term memory store information permanently

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of long-term memory?

options.label: B
options.text: Taking a picture with a camera

options.label: C
options.text: Remembering a childhood memory or a familiar skill, such as riding a bike

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of focus in transferring information from sensory memory to short-term memory?

options.label: C
options.text: It helps to selectively transfer information that is relevant or important

options.label: D
options.text: It helps to store information permanently

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between sensory memory and short-term memory?

options.label: B
options.text: Sensory memory is a part of short-term memory

options.label: C
options.text: Short-term memory is a part of sensory memory

options.label: D
options.text: They are separate entities that interact with each other

Conceptual Question:

options.label: A
